title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.9.26 | 23-04-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: but the summary is given here
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the topic of discussion, verse 26 from the 9th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, and explains that it is a summary of a detailed conversation in the Mahabharata about Varna and Ashrama Dharma.
segments.transcript: In this session, we will be discussing from the 26th verse of the 9th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam: Purushasvabhava Vihitam Yathavarnam Yathashramam Vairagya Rago Padibhyam Amnatobhaya Lakshanam. The meaning of this verse is: At Maharaj Yudhishthira's inquiry, Bhishma Deva first defined all the classifications of caste and orders of life in terms of the individual's qualifications. Then he systematically, in two-fold divisions, described counteraction by detachment and interaction by attachment. So the description continues by Suta Goswami to the sages of Naimisharanya that this conversation between Yudhishthira making inquiry about caste and orders of life, about dharma, and Bhishma replying is given in great details in the Mahabharata, but the summary is given here.

segments.key_quote: Everything goes by quality not by birth
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on Varna Dharma, explaining the four divisions of society (Brahmanas, Kshatriyas, Vaishyas, and Shudras) based on their acquired nature and occupational duties, emphasizing that it is based on qualification, not birth.
segments.transcript: So Bhishma first of all explained Varna Dharma. A civilized society is divided into four Varanas based on occupational duties, occupational engagements, according to their acquired nature. So those in Sattva Guna, their acquired nature is suitable for doing Brahmanical duties: Brahmanas. Kshatriyas, their acquired nature is Rajoguna. So they are suited for doing occupation of a Kshatriya: administrative duties, protection against harm of the innocent people, saintly persons, weaker sections of society. And the Vaishyas, their acquired nature is a mixed mode of passion and ignorance. So they are suited for doing Vaishya duties. They are the economic generators of the society. And the Shudras are mostly in the mode of ignorance, and they are mentioned in the Mahabharata. They are meant for doing some labor. They are meant to engage in the service of the upper three divisions: Brahmanas, Kshatriyas, and Vaishyas. Everything goes by quality, not by birth, not by some hereditary title. No. It goes by qualification. So in terms of the individual's qualifications, he described Varana Dharma. What is Brahmana Dharma? What is Kshatriya Dharma? What is Vaishya Dharma? What is Shudra Dharma?

segments.key_quote: Everyone should get free from bondage
segments.summary: The speaker briefly mentions Ashrama Dharma, the spiritual divisions of life, and emphasizes that the ultimate goal of both Varna and Ashrama Dharma is to liberate everyone from material bondage.
segments.transcript: And he described the Dharma of the different Ashramas. Ashrama is spiritual division: Brahmachari, Grahastha, Vanaprastha, Sanyas. So Brahmachari Dharma, Grahastha Dharma, Vanaprastha Dharma, Sanyas Dharma, everything Bheeshma Deva described systematically. Then he also described counteraction by detachment and interaction by attachment. So Srila Prabhupada explains these things in the purport. Prabhupada has written elaborate purport. I don't have time to go through the whole purport. I will try to cover some important points that the conception of the four Varanas and four Ashramas as planned by the Lord Himself, as described in the Bhagavad Gita: Chatur Varnyam Mayasrishtam Gunakarma Vibhagshah, is to accelerate transcendental qualities of the individual person so that he may gradually realize his spiritual identity and thus act accordingly to get free from material bondage with your conditional life. See, the goal is that everybody should be freed from bondage, not just the brahmanas, not just some few educated or learned people. No. Everyone should get free from bondage, and that's possible by following the Dharma. Anyone and everyone can actually become liberated.

segments.summary: The speaker addresses the common misunderstanding of Varnashrama Dharma as a system of artificial domination, clarifying that it is meant to train individuals for self-realization and liberation, distinguishing human life from the activities of animals.
segments.transcript: That is the whole idea. In the Mahabharata, it is most elaborately explained by Bhishma Deva in the Shanti Parva beginning from the 60th chapter. Prabhupada has given reference. Where do you get details? Here it is briefly explained. It is just mentioned. It is not even explained. But Prabhupada gives a little explanation here. Now the Varnashrama Dharma is most often misunderstood, especially in the modern times, that this caste system has created artificial domination of Brahmanas or Brahmanas and Kshatriyas over the other sections of society. No. That is not Varnashrama Dharma. That is a misinterpretation. That is the degradation of the Varnashrama Dharma. When unqualified people claim to be Brahmanas or Kshatriyas, they tend to exploit the weaker sections of society. That is not Varnashrama Dharma. So Varnashrama Dharma is prescribed for the civilized human being just to train him to successfully terminate human life. What is successful termination of human life? Self-realization to attain self-realization and thereby become free from material bondage.

segments.key_quote: One cannot be called a civilized person without acquiring the above mentioned preliminary qualities
segments.summary: The speaker outlines nine preliminary qualities necessary for a civilized person, according to Bhishma Deva, and mentions that each Varna has specific occupational duties outlined in the Vedas.
segments.transcript: So self-realization is distinguished from the life of the lower animals who are simply engaged in four activities: eating, sleeping, fearing, and mating. So Bhishma Deva advised for all human beings, not just for Brahmanas or not just for some people. No, 9 qualifications. What are they? Not to become angry, not to lie, not to equally distribute wealth, to forgive, to beget children only by one's legitimate wife, to be pure in mind and hygienic in body, not to be inimical toward anyone, to be simple. And the ninth one is to support servants or subordinates. It is explained here by Srila Prabhupada based on the description given by Bhishma Deva in the Mahabharata. One cannot be called a civilized person without acquiring the above mentioned preliminary qualities. Then there are specific qualities by which Brahmanas work, the Kshatriyas work, the Vaishyas work, and the Shudras work. Everybody has got specific occupational duties mentioned in the Vedas.

segments.key_quote: controlling the senses is the most essential qualification
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the specific duties of Brahmanas (controlling the senses), Kshatriyas (giving charity), and how their roles contribute to a perfect society where Brahmanas guide and enlighten the population.
segments.transcript: Now briefly Prabhupada says for the intelligent men, that is the Brahmanas, controlling the senses is the most essential qualification. Now it is the basis of morality. Why control the senses? It is the basis of morality. So if an intelligent man abuses his position, if he does not follow the Vedic way of life, he should seriously study Vedic literatures, especially Bhagavatam and Bhagavad Gita, and it is imperative that such a person willing to study should approach a bona fide spiritual master. He should not do anything which is forbidden in the Shastra. For the Kshatriya, it is especially advised to give charity and never accept charity in any circumstances. Kshatriya especially should give charity. So the Kshatriyas were meant to support the Brahmanas by giving them profuse charity, and thereby the Brahmanas could give free service to everyone in the society in matter of guiding them, giving them direction, enlightening them, and helping them whenever they were in difficulty. So this is the perfect society as described

segments.key_quote: they should be severely chastised by using violence by the Kshatriyas
segments.summary: The speaker describes the duties of Kshatriyas (protecting the weaker sections), Vaishyas (protecting cows and growing grains), and Shudras (rendering service), emphasizing the importance of each role in maintaining social order.
segments.transcript: in the Shastras. Now one of the important duties of the Kshatriya is to actually protect the weaker sections of the society, the rest of the society, by not pretending to become non-violent when there is a need to chastise the miscreants, the rogues, the thieves, the plunderers. They should be severely chastised by using violence by the Kshatriyas. Then the Vaishyas, they should particularly protect cows and grow sufficient grains and agriculture and distribution of foodstuff, especially meant for the Vaishyas, and Kshatriyas were given charge of protection of the citizens. Vaishyas were given charge of protection of the cows, Goraksh, and they used to produce profusely agricultural produce and milk and milk products. And then the Shudras, they have no independence because they are not sufficiently intelligent enough to use their independence, so they are meant to render sincere service to the upper three sections so that they can get all their comforts of life simply by rendering service to the higher classes because as soon as a Shudra accumulates wealth, he should never be given money because as soon as he accumulates wealth, it will be misused for sinful activities in wine, women, and gambling.

segments.key_quote: population becomes degraded to the level of Shudras
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the degradation of the population in Kali Yuga and the importance of providing for the needs of Shudras without giving them money, ensuring their satisfaction and preventing misuse of wealth.
segments.transcript: And that's what we see happening today. Whoever is not intelligent enough to utilize accumulated wealth, they will misuse it for sinful activities, and that's what is happening. Population becomes degraded. In Kali Yuga, it is said population becomes degraded to the level of Shudras or even lower than that, Chandala. The Shudras should always be provided with all the necessities without giving them money so that they are satisfied in all respects and they don't have accumulated wealth to misuse them. And the upper three sections, they should maintain the Shudras under all circumstances. Never should the Shudras be abandoned by any of the upper sections.

segments.summary: The speaker briefly explains the Ashramas (Brahmachari, Grahastha, Vanaprastha, Sanyas) as progressive stages for developing spiritual qualities and achieving self-realization, highlighting the roles of attachment and detachment in different Ashramas, and concludes the lecture.
segments.transcript: And the Ashramas, the student life Brahmachari, Grahastha the householder life, the retired life Vanaprastha, and the renounced life, it is progressively meant for developing spiritual qualities and progressing in self-realization systematically, and that is also explained by Bhishma Deva in detail. And the household life is for one who is attached, and Vanaprastha and Sanya's orders of life are meant for those who are detached. Hmm, householders are generally attached to family and so many family paraphernalia, but the Brahmachari Ashram is especially meant for training both the attached and the detached so that the goal is self-realization. Either somebody is attached or somebody is detached, but the goal is self-realization. That should not be forgotten. So I will stop here. Thank you very much.
